user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAccept_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *sock_token, const OS_object_token_t *conn_token,
                           OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    uint32                          operation;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *sock_impl;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;

    sock_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *sock_token);
    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *conn_token);

    operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
    if (sock_impl->selectable)
    {
        return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(sock_token, &operation, timeout);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE) == 0)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
        }
        else
        {
            addrlen       = Addr->ActualLength;
            conn_impl->fd = accept(sock_impl->fd, (struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData, &addrlen);
            if (conn_impl->fd < 0)
            {
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                Addr->ActualLength = addrlen;

                OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS(conn_token);
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAccept_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is reassigned within OS_SocketAccept_Impl. Specifically:
- sock_token and conn_token are only dereferenced via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *sock_token) and similar; this reads the object token value and does not assign to the pointer parameter itself.
- sock_token and conn_token are passed to other functions/macros (OS_SelectSingle_Impl, OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS) but there is no assignment to the parameter variables in this function. Calling another function with a pointer parameter is permitted; the rule only forbids modifying the parameter variable (the pointer) itself.
- Addr is used to read and write its pointed-to members (addrlen = Addr->ActualLength; Addr->ActualLength = addrlen; and passing &Addr->AddrData). Modifying the object pointed to by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule; there is no assignment to the Addr pointer itself (no "Addr = ..."), so this is compliant.
- timeout (an integer parameter) is only passed through; it is not assigned to or modified.
- The accept call assigns to conn_impl->fd and uses Addr members; these modify underlying objects, not the pointer parameters.
- The additional helper OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl similarly dereferences the token to index the table and modifies fields of the retrieved impl record (impl->selectable), but does not assign to the token parameter itself.

Therefore there are no fragments in the provided code that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (no pointer parameter variables are modified). If any of the used macros/functions (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_IMPL_SET_SOCKET_FLAGS, or OS_SelectSingle_Impl) contain code that assigns to their pointer-parameter variables, those macro/function definitions should be inspected; however, based on their usage here they operate on the objects referred to by the tokens rather than reassigning the token parameters themselves.
